author: oaklandmatt
content:
For the second question, the "car test" is a staple mostly because both sonically and psychologically, the car is a great counterbalance to the context and precision of the studio. 

The car is also the place most people used to listen to the most music as a fan. It still is for many, but I say "used to" because a lot of people's #1 music listening environment outside of a studio is the phone/ headphones/ AirPods. 

So my "car test" is now AirPod max headphones walking around my neighborhood in LA or taking the tube in London. 

But the car also has its advantages because it's noisy and imperfect and NOT isolated like the studio and headphones. You can't listen as precisely in a car, which often tells you very quickly whether you can hear the important parts of your song (can you hear the vocal? Does the low end feel good?).

author: cian riordan
content: Hi Rae, these are awesome headphones but -- like any closed back headphone -- it's going to be hard to get a real sense of how things are going translate in the real world..  especially when it comes to low end. Everything on headphones is going to sound clear and direct, when that may not be the case coming through speakers. Checking stuff on some decent monitors in a decent room -- or even in your car --  is always the best way to know if things sound off or not. If you're stuck with headphones, something open back like a Sennheiser 600 will give you a less-hyped, more honest picture of your mix. They're also much less fatiguing to work on for long periods of time! But even to this day with my nice setup, I'm always checking the low end in different places... In my car, I'll know within 10 seconds of listening if things are where they're supposed to be or not.

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: Also better monitoring might just take you from point A to B quicker. IME if I have to mix on closed backs it ends up being a slower process even if the end result may be similar as to open backs

author: Adam Thein
content: Swapping headphones feels like getting a new prescription on your glasses after several years.  The signatures can be so wildly different and it typically takes me 6-8 weeks of listening to them regularly to get well adjusted.  I wouldn’t recommend switching out monitoring in general mid-project - better to use what you know and get to the finish line than to suddenly add a lot of doubt to the work.

author: cian riordan
content: There's some standards that are useful -- outs over ins, normalling strategy... that type of stuff. Really comes down to what you're trying to achieve. If you're operating a big tracking studio, then you want that workflow in mind: tie lines normalled to mic pres, mic outs normalled to A/D inputs, D/A outs normalled to monitor controller & headphone boxes, etc. If you're in a mixing room (like me), I have things setup so outboard gear is accessible via hardware inserts through patchbay normalization. As for labelling, I've been using my own spreadsheet system that I find more useful than patchbay labelling software. Here's an example of my setup from last year:

author: cian riordan
content: Your results will almost always be attributed to your skills! In this case, while I'd focus my attention on getting some reps in on various mixing projects, there's certainly room to grow in your equipment stable. Headphones are a great starting point and will likely continue to be useful down the road, but mixing on speakers helps you make things translate better to the real world (car & home stereos, public spaces, etc). So a pair of decent entry level monitors would be my next purchase. It will also prove useful for collaborating with other folks down the road as you can all hear the same thing from the same source.

author: 1ggy
content: https://thehomerecordings.com/open-back-headphones-for-mixing/   check this out

author: antoniohannamusic
content: Agree with this, also, one thing for 'live sessions" is that by the time Cameras have filmed 5 x takes to get coverage it's often no longer strictly 'live' obviously there are exceptions. For location recordings though, Isolation is absolutely key, if everyone can play with IEM's or is happy to wear headphones then I would normally DI everything, Mic up a drumkit and give the singer an SM7B having them sing directly at the drummer (obviously not always possible) then everyone else, bass, keys, guitar, DI, pick an amp sim / keys plugin and get them to do multiple passes (to a click if possible). Not trying to be prescriptive just my approach FWIW.

author: Eric Martin
content:
I see a lot of the Telefunken M80, I started using a beyer M88 TG, the pattern is super tight and it sounds tuned nice for my voice.

It all depends on the performance style, if there’s a live band, size of the stage if there’s a live band.

We tried a KSM8 with my live pop/rock band and the size stages we play on are too small for it to work, it always captures too much drums, switched to a 58 and everything cleaned up better.

If it’s for you, go to a store where you can hear yourself singing into the mic through a PA, not through headphones, that will help you determine if it sounds good.

author: cian riordan
content: I’ll use quick car trips or time on headphones while traveling to dig in outside the studio. Always nice perspective when it’s possible.

author: LAPhill
content: If you're doing any kind of office or flex space, be very up front about what you'll use the room for. They're not going to have much isolation, and other people renting aren't going to necessarily want to put up with it during business hours. I had a couple friends do that, and they had to use headphones during the day until everyone left. They were fine with it, but it would've been a real drag for me. (Also limiting in terms of when you can have client playbacks, vocal sessions, etc.)

author: Colin Althaus
content: Just one opinion - I've spent quite a bit of time on the Sennheiser 58X (similar to the 650s) and recently moved to the Airpods Max. That family of Sennheisers are on the better end of wired / open-back headphones for sure, but I never got to the point of trusting them fully for mix translation. I experimented a bit with adding an Oratory EQ (using RME Room EQ on my interface) and that improved them quite a bit - much less of a mental adjustment when switching back to my Genelecs. The Airpods Max to me sound similar to the EQ-corrected Sennheisers, but with a more extended low end. Also the noise cancellation is great (love switching it on while mixing FOH!) I've started mixes on them and had very few translation surprises when switching back to monitors, albeit I still don't trust them enough to finish a mix yet.  For the price I think it's actually a great deal for what you get, considering Audezes are at least 2-3x the cost and  still need EQ to sound their best imho.

author: 1ggy
content: I use DT 880 Pro's. They're super comfortable, semi open back, and have a pretty flat feq response curve (ie accurate/true representation of the mix). And, not at a bad price.

author: Deleted User
content: Yeah, as long as the monitors translate for you, that sounds like the better option. With headphones often compromises have to be made, especially in the lower price brackets, so definitely try before you buy, and try formulating what you would want from a headphone(good bass, clear transients, more even/neutral response, etc. etc.)

author: Deleted User
content: To my ears M50s sound very congested, especially in comparison to their direct competition - Beyer 770s(I own both). The transients(which for me are absolutely crucial to hear when producing or mixing) are almost inaudible on the M50s, while decently audible on the 770s. I do not find the M50s or the 770s even close to "well balanced", they both are a bit too budget for that distinction(they both have extreme presence peaks at their respective frequencies). I know someone who is very happy with the Shure SRH940s and Shure 1840s for critical listening(same drivers, I think). The M50s and 770s are both pretty much unusable in the low end under 50-60hz for me, I don't feel they translate well there. A few mastering engineers use the Blue closed-back headphones as a low-end reference, they would probably be worth a try. Audeze stuff is pretty good for transient response, but more expensive.

author: Josh
content: I have the ATH-R70x and it’s very much the same thing. The mid range is very clear but low and high end is a jumbled mess. Only reason I still have them is because I don’t like working on headphones and they’re super lightweight and comfortable to wear

author: Rob Domos
content:
Just reading through what you and @river were talking about and I’d like to balance this perspective out a little bit.

While I’d agree that things like midside EQ can make things sound strange in a way I don’t like, I’m not shying away from decoupling the mids from the sides in general or saying M/S = Bad. Turning down the M channel on elements that I want to have be more background surrounding elements with a plugin like CenterOne is actually one of my most common mix moves and it sounds great.

A good friend of mine who has made one of my favorite mixes of all time constantly talks about his use of M/S processing. I don’t do much M/S other than levels and stereo imagining, but my boi does regularly and he sounds great. 

All that to say: River,  It’s worth being careful and listening to what could be getting fucked up in your midside processing, I wouldn’t be M/S EQing personally, and you should generally only do M/S moves with speakers and generally not with headphones, but that doesn’t mean that you should shy away from M/S all together if it sounds really good to you. Lots of great engineers are using it all the time.

author: BoozleBAM
content: I'm curious: Does anyone here have any insight into the drum sound on Foo Fighters "My Hero?" It's a really wild drum sound. Whenever I'm driving and that song comes on the radio it always piques my interest... I've been sifting through a few different reference tracks recently, and I just listened to it on headphones for the first time. They do some really wild stereo stuff with the drums in the intro and the chorus - You can hear it really pronounced on headphones. It's actually a little disconcerting hearing the cymbals basically mirroring each other in the left and right like that - and the snare, too. The cymbals also have a very pronounced "BWEEESHHH..." sound. It's a very unique sound... I suspect there were a lot of room mics going on in that sound, but of course I have no idea. Anyway, would love to hear from anyone who might know.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: There can be capacitance issues on long runs, which can on occasion destabilize a headphone amp

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I wouldn’t do a long run like this at headphone level

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: And no problem to split the headphone signal to two headphones, but be aware that if they are not the same they can play at different levels depending on impedance

author: David Fuller

author: BoozleBAM
content: Any distinct advantages to mixing on open back vs closed back headphones? Anything I might be being short sighted about and possibly missing? Got some really nice open back cans the other day (akg k701). They sound absolutely SUPERB, but I'm not super into the whole open back experience if I'm honest.

author: cian riordan
content: Pros and cons, like anything else. Open back tend to have a more neutral response… almost closer to being on speakers. Less fatiguing. Downside is lack of isolation from outside world, lack of low/high end “hype”. Neither are a panacea and both will have their issues with translation to the outside world. I can mix in headphones because I’ve mixed in good sounding rooms as built up good practices - with good results - for 20 years. But it isn’t my ideal. I would almost always trust a decent sounding — even unideal room before solely relying on them.

I'm not the hugest fan of them for mixing, but they sound just fantastic. Wondering if I might want to hang onto them just for that reason alone.

author: Zack Hames
content:
My fav guitar mics from brightest to darkest 

sm57 for classic, biting, bright, aggressive guitars 
md441 for huge but smooth high end
beyerdynamic m160 for extra mids or smoother highs 
RCA 74B for fender style amps 
Coles 4038 for extra bright or harsh amps

author: Zack Hames

author: BoozleBAM
content: So, I've tested this a lot. The wording might sound weird: If I have the click track "too loud" in my headphones, I end up adapting with my drumming and my drumming kind of sucks a little bit - I end up compensating with my hits subconsciously because Im' kind of letting the click track "hit" for me. If that makes any sense. The way I can get around this is by having the click so that I can barely hear it. Only thing is, my drumming can be a little... less tight this way, and some measure of beat detective might have to be invoked at some point, if you get what I'm saying...
